title: Multiple SARS-CoV-2 introductions shaped the early outbreak in Central Eastern Europe: comparing Hungarian data to a worldwide sequence data-matrix
author: 1 Virological Research Group BSL-4 Laboratory, Szentágothai Research Centre, University of Pécs, Pécs, Hungary 2 Institute of Biology, Faculty of Sciences, University of Pécs, Pécs, Hungary 3 National Coronavirus Research Centre, University of Pécs, Pécs, Hungary 4 Institute for Veterinary Medical Research, Centre for Agricultural Research, Budapest, Hungary 5 University of Veterinary Medicine Budapest, Centre for Bioinformatics, Budapest, Hungary 6 Translational Discovery, Stromal Biology, Bristol-Myers Squibb, Princeton, NJ, USA 7 National Food Safety Office, Budapest, Hungary 8 Szentágothai Research Centre, Bioinformatics Research Group, Genomics and Bioinformatics Core Facility, University of Pécs, Pécs, Hungary. 9 Clinical Research Centre, Medical University of Bialystok, Bialystok, Poland 10 Hungarian Defense Forces, Military Medical Centre, Budapest, Hungary 11 Institute of Clinical Microbiology, University of Szeged, Faculty of Medicine, Szeged, Hungary 12 Independent researcher, Vantaa, Finland 13 Institute for Computer Science and Control, Hungarian Academy of Sciences 14 Central Hospital of Southern Pest, Budapest đ These authors contributed equally

abstract: Severe Acute Respiratory Syndrome Coronavirus 2 is the third highly pathogenic human coronavirus in history. Since the emergence in Hubei province, China, during late 2019 the situation evolved to pandemic level. Following China, Europe was the second epicenter of the pandemic. To better comprehend the detailed founder mechanisms of the epidemic evolution in Central-Eastern Europe, particularly in Hungary, we determined the full-length SARSCoV-2 genomes from 32 clinical samples collected from laboratory confirmed COVID-19 patients over the first month of disease in Hungary. We applied a haplotype network analysis on all available complete genomic sequences of SARS-CoV-2 from GISAID database as of the 21th of April, 2020. We performed additional phylogenetic and phylogeographic analyses to achieve the recognition of multiple and parallel introductory events into our region. Here we present a publicly available network imaging of the worldwide haplotype relations of SARS-CoV-2 sequences and conclude the founder mechanisms of the outbreak in CentralEastern Europe.
